metadata.title: Comparative study to use nano-(Al2O3, CuO, and SiC) with water to enhance photovoltaic thermal PV/T collectors

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Energy Conversion and Management
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/ locate /enconman
Comparative study to use nano-(Al2O3, CuO, and SiC) with water to enhance photovoltaic thermal PV/T collectors
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.enconman.2017.06.072 0196-8904/ 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: ali9alwaeli@gmail.com (A.H.A. Al-Waeli), h.kazem@soharuni.
edu.om (H.A. Kazem).
Ali H.A. Al-Waeli a,⇑, Miqdam T. Chaichan b, Hussein A. Kazem c,⇑, K. Sopian a a Solar Energy Research Institute, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600 Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia b Energy and Renewable Energies Technology Research Center, University of Technology, Baghdad, Iraq c Faculty of Engineering, Sohar University, PO Box 44, Sohar PCI 311, Oman
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 4 May 2017 Received in revised form 23 June 2017 Accepted 24 June 2017
Keywords: PVT collector Nanofluids Nanoparticles Indoor Density Viscosity Stability
a b s t r a c t
The reduction in efficiency of photovoltaic (PV) units due to increases in cell temperature occurs when a small part of the absorbed solar radiation is converted into electricity and the remaining part is lost as heat. Recently, the addition of a range of nanomaterials with high thermal conductivity to the cooling fluid in PV/T systems has been the subject of much research. In this study, three nanomaterials were added to water as a base fluid with several volume fractions to determine the best concentration and nanoparticle for this application. The PV/T system was setup in an indoor laboratory. Knowing which material has a better effect on the PV unit in particular, and the PV/T unit in general, is important for deciding which nanomaterial is more suitable for the system. The results reveal that nanofluid gives higher thermal conductivity with very little increase in the fluid density and viscosity compared with the base fluid. The studied volume fractions were 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 4% and the selected nanoparticles were Al2O3, CuO, and SiC. It was found that silicon carbide nanoparticles have the best stability and the highest thermal conductivity compared to the other two nano-substances. Copper oxide nanofluid has higher thermal conductivity than aluminium oxide but lower stability, although it was found here that this material reliably stable compared to in other studies. The nanofluid reduced the indoor PV/T system temperature and enhanced its generated power.
2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The use of nanofluids in solar heat exchangers is a recently developed way to improve heat transfer properties. Moreover, adding nanomaterial to conventional heat transfer fluids improves their thermal properties [1]. The use of nanofluids in solar heat exchangers has attracted considerable attention by researchers recently due to the significant improvement in heat transfer compared to conventional fluids [2].
Maxwell [3] first noted that the addition of solid particles to conventional heat transfer fluids enhances their thermal conductivity. However, dispersion is problematic for solid particles in liquids as they accumulate, leading to their sedimentation. This causes a consequent blockage of flow paths, corrosion of flow pipes walls, and an increased pressure drop. In 1993, study by Masuda et al. [4] indicated that a combination of micrometre size solid particles and conventional heat transfer fluids could enhance thermal
conductivity. However, researchers have encountered the problem of the deposition of particles at the base of the liquid’s container, which reduces the utility of thermal conductivity. In a later study, Choi [5] managed to prepare liquids containing nanometre-sized materials. He observed a significant improvement in the thermal conductivity of the resulting fluid. Moreover, the dispersion of nanometre-sized particles in conventional liquids was sufficient and resulted in stability and a suspension without precipitation. The benefits of using nanomaterials in fluids come from the fact that they provide a higher surface area than that of conventional fluids. Many researchers have studied the benefits of adding these nanomaterials to fluids and applications that can take advantage of the enhancement in heat transfer, especially solar collectors. Table 1 lists some of these studies.
Table 1 shows some of the experimental and numerical works conducted on the thermal behaviour of different types of nanoparticles operating in applications with heat exchangers of different geometries. For the interested reader, many review papers have highlighted this work in detail [16–20].
Photovoltaic cells (PV) are made of semiconductor materials which produce electricity by converting sunlight radiation which
stimulates electrons. As only a fraction of the solar spectrum is utilized in this process to excite electrons to create electron-hole pairs, the photovoltaic cells have limited electrical efficiency. Photovoltaic cells mainly absorb the solar spectrum between 700 nm and 1100 nm. Shorter or longer wavelengths are not collected [21,22] but converted to heat that can reduce cell efficiency or, to some extent, cause damage [23].
In contrast, solar thermal energy collectors (consisting of a heat transfer fluid inside a tube or container with a solid surface that absorbs heat) can utilize the entire solar spectrum [24]. In recent years, nanofluids have been explored as more efficient cooling liquids than air and water. This property was applied to cool PV cells and was referred to as a hybrid thermal photoelectric cell [25]. Many studies have shown that hybrid PV/T is more efficient than individual photovoltaic or thermal systems because it benefits from most of the incident solar energy [26,27]. The low temperature of the photovoltaic cell increases its output capacity and the heat absorbed by the solar collector can be used in other applications. Table 2 summarizes some of the recent works in this field.
As Table 2 indicates, there are major achievements in the field of employing nanoparticles to cool down PV/T systems, but as many researchers have pointed out, there are still many aspects under discussion such as thermal absorber design, materials used, coating, cost minimization, conservation of energy, performance testing and control. Research is under way to overcome the difficulties associated with the use of nanofluids in PV/T systems.
In this investigation, three types of nanoparticles will be studied. These nanoparticles were chosen from a group of species that had two important properties, namely high thermal conductivity and moderate prices. Also, these materials have been used in previous research works dealing with PV/T systems, which give an important comparison of all properties studied with previous literature. For example, Al2O3 was investigated in Refs. [7,9,10]; Refs. [43–45] studied the use of CuO, and SiC was investigated in Refs. [47,48,50]. Since the size of the system used is 12 l, the amount of nanoparticles used was 0.2717 kg of CuO, 0.14 kg for alumina,
and 0.1592 kg of silicon carbide. These quantities have reasonable prices in the local markets all over the word (1 US dollar/g) which confirm the good selection if these materials. Nanoparticles will be used to form nanofluids with water and the resulting fluid cooling efficiency will be evaluated in an indoor PV/T system using a solar simulator to control the solar intensity variation. The aim of the current study is to determine which ratios are more suitable for mixing nanomaterials with water with regard to thermophysical properties, the maximum output of electrical and thermal energies and efficiency.

sections.heading: 2.1. The indoor PV/T simulator
sections.text:
A thermal solar energy basic unit ‘‘MINI-EESTC”, made in Italy, was used as an indoor solar simulator. The rig consists of a solar collector made of tempered glass whose surface was replaced by a copper plate to operate as a heat transfer agent. A PV panel is placed above the upper plate, whose specifications are listed in Table 3. The back of the panel and the top plate surfaces were painted with silicone oil to avoid any air gaps that may reduce the heat transfer from the panel to the collector. Inside the collector, there is a copper pipe mesh welded to a copper plate to increase the heat transfer rate. Above of the photovoltaic cell there are fifteen bright lights installed to provide variable intensity of 0– 1500W/m2 controlled by the control panel as a solar simulator. This simulator has a fluid circulating pump that gives options to operate the system in forced or natural convection. However, in this study, the natural convection heat transfer mode was used. When the PV panel is heated, it transfers its accumulated heat to the collector causing the temperature of the working fluid inside to increase. Water movement can be achieved by natural convection due to the difference in temperature between the cold fluid in the tank and hot fluid in the collector or by using a pump (forced

As Fig. 1 shows, five temperature sensors are used in this experiment including a room temperature sensor; it is well known that not all of the electric power is transformed into luminous power (there is an efficiency factor), as well as, not all of the radiant power is applied to the panel. For this reason, three curtains surround the collector from three sides while the fourth side is blocked by the fluid tank base. In addition to a fluid pump, four thermocouples are attached to measure variable system temperatures. Table 3 shows the specifications of the PV panel to provide an accurate understanding of its behaviour.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nanofluid preparation
sections.text:
To date, no perfect method has been determined for the preparation and processing of stable nanofluids. Therefore, after each mixing process, the thermophysical properties of the resulting suspension must be examined. Nanoparticles of alumina (Al2O3), silicon carbide (SiC), and copper oxide (CuO) were used as provided by the manufacturer. Table 4 lists the studied nanomaterials specifications, which helps in identifying its behaviour and tracking changes after the mixing process is complete.
The nanoparticles were heated using an oven to eliminate any accompanying moisture. The heating was done for a quarter of an hour with an oven temperature of 200 C. Nanofluids were formed using different weight ratios of the studied nanoparticles and deionized water.
The repeated experiments proved that it is hard to prepare nanofluid at the desired concentration with water without adding any surfactant. For this reason, a minuscule amount (about 0.1 ml) of cetyl-trichromyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) was added. The nanoparticle material was weighed using an analytical balance (EJ6I0-E).
The mixing of nanomaterials with water is a crucial process: it determines the success or failure of the mixture. Water was poured inside an ultrasonic shaker (TELSONIC ULTRASONICS CT-I2) with a basin size of 12 l. The nanoparticles were added slowly to the bath at intervals. The bath vibrated continuously for 12 h to ensure that the nanoparticle agglomerations break down and form a homogeneous and stable suspension. Variable volumetric concentrations of nanoparticles were prepared (0.5, 1.0, 2, 3 and 4) for each material. The required quantity of nanoparticles needed for a particular volume concentration was calculated using the following equation:
/% ¼ ðmp=qpÞðmp=qpÞ þ ðmf =qf Þ ð1Þ
Since suspended fluid stability is crucial to maintaining its thermophysical properties, the deposition of a part of the nanoparticle significantly affects these properties. Therefore, after each mixing process, a sample of the mixture was taken and kept in a glass bottle. The stability of the suspension and settling rate are checked every three months. Fine details on the topographic surface of the studied nanoparticles were studied using Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM). Fig. 2 shows the SEM images taken for each of the studied nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2.3. Thermophysical property measurements
sections.text:
Thermophysical and rheological properties of the prepared nanofluid were predicted experimentally as follows:
1. Density measurements: The density of the prepared suspensions was measured by weighing a sample (250 ml) for each concentration of nanomaterial and then dividing the weight by the volume. Multiple Refs. [33,36,37] have suggested that the base liquid is the most important factor affecting the density of nanofluids, while other variables such as the size and shape of the nanoparticles have limited effect.
2. Viscosity measurements: A Brookfield programmable viscometer (model: LVDV-III ultra-programmable) was used to measure the viscosities of the nanofluid suspensions. This device is interfaced with a personal computer for data collection and storage. 3. Thermal conductivity measurements: The thermal conductivity of the studied nanofluids was explored using a HOT DESK Tps 500 thermal conductivity meter (KIJTALEY, Sweden). This thermal constant analyser uses a standard isotropic method for ranges from 0.03 to 100W/m K. The measuring time ranges from 2.5 to 2560 s. The instrument accuracy is higher than 97.5%.
4. Specific heat measurements: The specific heat of the studied nanofluids was measured using a heat colorimeter apparatus (ESD-201).
All density, viscosity, thermal conductivity, and specific heat experiments were repeated three times to confirm repeatability, and the mean value was taken to reduce the uncertainty resulting from the random error in the measurement. The following equations were used in the system performance:
The system’s thermal efficiency is:
gth ¼ Qu
Is Ac ð2Þ
where Is is the solar intensity and Ac is the collector area. The electrical power is:
P ¼ I V ð3Þ where I - is the current and V - is the voltage.
The useful collected heat (W)
Qu ¼ _mCpðTo TiÞ ð4Þ where _m is the mass flow rate, Cp is the specific heat (J/kg K) and To and Ti are outlet and inlet fluid temperatures, respectively (ST-2 and ST-1 in Fig. 1).
The electrical efficiency ge is:
ge ¼ P
Is Apanel ð5Þ
where Apanel is the PV panel area. The total efficiency (gt) = the thermal efficiency + the electrical efficiency gt ¼ gth þ ge ¼ Qu þ P Is At ð6Þ
where At is the total area of the PV panel and collector.

sections.heading: 2.4. Experimental errors and uncertainties
sections.text:
The experimental error was analysed by calibrating all measuring devices used in this study. The experimental error is the difference between the measured and real quantity, and the determination of the value of this error determines a certain uncertainty in the measurement for each experiment. The definition of uncertainty described by Ref. [38] was used:
eR ¼ @R @V1 e1 2 þ @R @V2 e2 2 þ þ @R @Vn en
2" #0:5 ð7Þ
where eR: uncertainty in the results. R: a given function of the independent variables V1, V2, . . . ,Vn or R = R(V1,V2, . . . ,Vn). ei: uncertainty interval in the nth variable. @R @V1 - The measured result sensitivity for a single variable.
Table 5 lists the calibration analysis of the experimental measuring property for the measuring devices used. The test uncertainties can be identified depending on these values as:
er ¼ ½ð0:78Þ2 þ ð1:01Þ2 þ ð0:68Þ2 þ ð0:35Þ2 þ ð0:023Þ2 þ ð0:89Þ2
þð1:12Þ2 þ ð0:34Þ2 0:5 ¼ 2:0951 The resulting uncertainty value was less than 5%, which indicates that an acceptable and reliable engineering border was achieved in the conducted tests. Table 5 is very important for assessing the accuracy of the produced results to be able to judge the effect these nanofluids hold on PV/T collectors.

sections.heading: 2.5. Experimental procedures
sections.text:
The first set of experiments undertaken was the mixing of nanoparticles with deionized water using the previously mentioned mixing method to prepare the required volume ratios. In the second stage, the density, viscosity, thermal conductivity and stability of the resulting nano-suspensions were examined. The validation of the results was achieved by comparing the study results with those of other studies. The primary objective was to determine the best mixing ratio between water and nanomaterials to use in the PV/T system to give the best performance.
After determining the optimum mixing ratio, experiments were conducted in the solar simulator system. The first experiment involved using water as a cooling fluid and to then compare with nanofluid. After the water tests, the nanofluids were applied to the system and the effect of each one studied on the system’s performance in detail. The outdoor solar intensity varies with time and many other weather parameters. The simulation of the outdoor solar intensity in an indoor device needs suitable simulation of the intensity and time parameters. For this purpose, the intensity of the luminous lights was varied by 150 W/m2 each hour between 7 AM and 12 PM. At the starting point, at 7 AM, the intensity used was 250W/m2. The luminous intensity was fixed for two hours (12 AM and 1 PM) at 1000 W/m2 and then it was reduced 200W/m2 each hour till 6 PM where it reached 0W/m2. For the comparison to be fair, two systems were used in this study: a water cooled PV/T system and a nanofluid cooling PV/T system. The study aimed to determine the best mixing ratio between the nanoparticles and water to give the best results in the PV/T system. Moreover, the study tried to identify the best nanomaterial between the three nanofluids employed to enhance such systems.

sections.heading: 3.1. Nanofluid density
sections.text:
Density is an important thermophysical property that must be studied, especially when adding a high-density material (nanomaterial) to water. A significant variation in intensity has a severe impact on the pumping force and reduces the amount of flowing fluid in the case of a high increase in density. Fig. 3 shows the density variation when nano-Al2O3, CuO, and SiC were added to water in variable volumetric fractions (VF). The nanofluid density increased with an increase in the nanoparticle volumetric fraction and is almost negligible in the case of small proportions such as 0.5 or 1%. The results show that the largest increase occurred when adding 4% VF. The increases in the used nanofluids density were 0.0012, 0.0057, and 0.002% for the Al2O3, CuO, and SiC nanofluids, respectively. When compared the addition of 3% nanoparticles to
water with water density, nano-Al2O3-water is found to be the closest to water density while nano-CuO-water is the farthest. SiC nanofluid density is relatively higher than the water density by a moderate rate and does not affect the pumping performance if a pump is used in the system. These results clearly show the effect of added nanoparticles’ size, its added rate to water, and the density of these substances on the resulting nanofluid density.

sections.heading: 3.2. Nanofluid viscosity
sections.text:
Viscosity is also an important property when employing nanoparticles in thermal applications, where the flow rate is a function of viscosity. Viscosity and its changes reflect the resistance of inertia when fluid flows into the system, so adequate information on nanofluid viscosity is necessary to design the proper pumping capacity for convection and heat transfer coefficient of any system [51]. Viscosity is no less important than thermal conductivity in engineering systems. Nanoparticles cause an increase in thermal conductivity, and it is believed that this increase cannot be achieved without a decrease in pressure, which in turns relates to viscosity. The viscosity resulting from adding nanoparticles to a fluid depends on many factors such as the liquid base, shape and size of the nanoparticles, surface tension and chemistry of particles, temperature, method of dispersion of nanoparticles in suspension, and the resulting nanofluid pH [52,53]. As the results in Fig. 4 show, the addition of nanoparticles to water increased its viscosity compared with water alone. The nanoparticles concentration increase in the nanofluids enhances the viscosity of the resulting liquid. Refs. [54–57] indicate that nanoparticles could aggregate, extend, and form a connected structure within nanofluids. Nanofluid viscosity is positively affected by aggregation, as the group size increases in comparison with the nanoparticles by a factor of four or five. Moreover, aggregation can be responsible for increasing viscosity over time which can
affect the flow. Viscosity is a function of temperature as it reduced with increasing the fluid’s temperature as the figure reveals. Increasing the VF from 0 to 4% increased the viscosity by 0.0076, 0.0039, and 0.0088% for the Al2O3, CuO, and SiC nanofluids, respectively. The figure shows that the addition of 3% nano-SiC results in higher viscosity compared to other substances. In general, the limited increase in viscosity of the studied nanofluids will be negligible when using a pump in the system.

sections.heading: 3.3. Thermal conductivity of nanofluids
sections.text:
Fig. 5 shows the thermal conductivity of the tested nanofluids as a function of VF and temperature. Thermal conductivity appears to increase non-linearly with an increase in nanoparticle VF as the figure indicates. The thermal conductivity of the nanofluids also increases for all concentrations with increasing temperature. The figure clearly shows that thermal conductivity increases with temperature. The main reason for this noticeable increase in temperature can be attributed to the added nanoparticles. The intensity of the Brownianmotion of nanoparticles increases as the temperature increase, allowing for greater heat flow between the particles that lead to thermal conductivity enhancement. Any addition, even as small as 0.5%, will improve the thermal conductivity of the resulting nanofluid. Increasing VF from 0 to 4% increases the thermal conductivity by 1.96, 3.42, and 4.8% for the Al2O3, CuO, and SiC nanofluids, respectively. When comparing the nanoparticles added with VF = 3%, the thermal conductivity of SiC nanofluid is observed to be higher than the other two fluids. This can be attributed to the high thermal conductivity of nano-SiC compared to the other two substances. These results show a clear dependence on the thermal conductivity of nanomaterials as the measured differences correspond to the difference between the conductivity of the nanoparticles used. Also, Between 50 and 60 C, the rate of increase in thermal conductivity for the CuO nanofluid decreases to become

Table 6 shows a comparison between the results obtained from the present study and those of other studies involving the same nanomaterials. Comparisons with other studies may not be insightful as though these studies employed nanoparticles of the same type; they had different sizes, as well as different mixing methods, aggregation rates and sedimentations (suspension stability). The results show an acceptable convergence, in general, for Al2O3 and CuO nanofluids. However, for SiC nanofluid, Refs. [47,48] results were little diverge compared to present study. For Ref. [47], the use of large nanoparticles (170 nm) reduces their surface area inside the fluid, resulting in degradation in the thermal conductivity of the nanofluid. In Ref. [48], the authors claimed that adding ethylene glycol (EG) to water reduces the thermal conductivity of the resulting base fluid. In Ref. [50], a high volume fraction (9%) was used which doubled the produced thermal conductivity compared to the present study. The current study has focused on the stability of the used nanofluids as long as possible, which prevented the increase of the added value of nanoparticles. The increase of the nanoparticles percentage means increasing its instability and its desire to accumulate and deposition.

sections.heading: 3.4. Nanofluid stability
sections.text:
The ability to use a nanomaterial in a fluid depends mainly on the possibility of nanoparticles to be suspended in the mixture for extended periods of time and not be deposited in the tubes or on the surfaces. In the current study, three different types of nanoparticles were mixed using a normal mixing method. It is
important to ensure that no nanoparticle is deposited and the mixture remains homogeneous and stable. The deposition of the studied materials has been verified visually by conserving nanoparticles in open containers. The volume fractions of all the studied nanofluids were stored in containers and the suspended fluid sedimentation was monitored. Fig. 6 shows the containers stored for the deposition examination. Attention should be paid to the difference in the colour of the solution as its darkness increases as the nanoparticle VF increases.
After a certain period, a few small clusters of nanoparticles appeared. Table 7 shows how much time elapsed before the nanoparticles were deposited at the bottom of the container. From the results in the table, it is evident that increasing the nanoparticle VF in the suspended solution increases the amount of deposition. SiC nanofluids remained suspended for longer periods compared to the other particles. This was also found in other studies [49,50,60]. The results also indicate that Al2O3 nanoparticles are more stable than CuO nanoparticles. The sedimentation experiment indicated that though small agglomerates might not be observable visually, however, the distribution in the primary fluid is still appropriate. CuO nanoparticles tend to aggregate more than the other materials studied and therefore deposition occurs at a faster rate.

sections.heading: 3.5. Nanofluids impact on PV/T system
sections.text:
The main purpose of using PV/T systems is to reduce the PV panels’ temperatures resulting from high solar radiation intensity. The higher the heat drawn from the panels, the more likely they are to maintain the panels at suitable temperatures close to 25 C and the better their output.
Table 6 Comparisons between the present study results and literatures.
Ref. Diameter size (nm) Volume concentration (vol.%) Thermal conductivity enhancement (%) Base fluid
Al2O3 Present study 30–60 4 1.69 Water Huang et al. [39] 40 2.84 8.1 Water Sundar et al. [40] 36.5 8 1.15 Ethylene glycol and water (50:50) Vijjha and Das [41] 53 4 1.45 Ethylene glycol and water (60:40) Minsta et al. [42] 47 0.17 1.3 Water
CuO Present study 35–45 4 3.42 Water Milanese et al. [43] 30 3 1.1 Water Vinodhan et al. [44] 22–28 1.7 2.1 Water Agarwal et al. [45] 55–66 2 2.6 Water Xuan et al. [46] 10 3 2 Water
SiC Present study 45–65 4 4.8 Water Yu et al. [47] 170 3.7 1.6 Water Li et al. [48] 30 15 1.6 Ethylene glycol (EG) Li and Zuo [49] 30 1 3.3 Water/EG Al-Waeli et al. [50] 45–65 9 8.4 Water
Fig. 7 illustrates the effect of luminous intensity of the tested fluids temperatures and the resulting power of the PV/T system. The temperature of the water increases significantly with an increase in radiation intensity, as the solar cell absorbs specific wavelengths, while the rest becomes heat in the cell body and is transferred to the water. The use of nanofluid reduced the resulting heat as it is rapidly transferred to the reservoir before eventually passing to the air depending on its high thermal conductivity. For this reason, the SiC nanofluid has the lowest measured temperature. The thermal powers of the nanofluids are higher than that
for water, and the highest one is that for SiC-water. The higher the heat drew from the cell, the higher the thermal power of the system. Nano-SiC-water nanofluid has practically proved to have the highest ability to reduce solar cell heat and gain maximum thermal power. Also, the heat dissipation from the cell helped to improve the resulted voltage and current, causing a higher electrical power as the figure shows. As Refs. [58,59] revealed that an increase in the PV panel’s temperature can cause a significant reduction in voltage while its effect on the current is limited. The temperatures of the nanofluids were lower than that of water
resulting in higher current and voltage which means better system performance. The increase in radiation intensity improves the cell’s power when its temperature is lowered. Hence, as the figure indicates, the resulting electrical power of the PV/T system is higher when SiC nanofluid is employed compared to all of the other fluids studied.
The present results show that the use of nanofluids improved the thermal conductivity of the base fluid, and hence the cooling of the photovoltaic cell which leads to higher power production.
However, the optimal fluid must be selected for this purpose. The results of the study indicate that SiC nanofluid showed the best results compared to all the other materials used.
Fig. 8 shows the effect of the tested nanofluids on the electrical and thermal powers of the PV/T system. In this figure, increasing the luminous intensity reduced the electrical efficiency for all the used cooling fluids while the thermal powers are increased. The reduction in the electrical efficiency means that the use of natural convection in cooling the PV/T system was not efficient and forced convection should be used instead. Natural convection gives the system enough time to heat exchange and thus increase the thermal efficiency of the system. The reduction in electrical efficiency is due to the increase in temperature with the increase of luminous intensity. However, the efficiency is higher in case of cooling by nanofluid compared with water. Certainly, the overall efficiency of the system has increased significantly when compared to a photovoltaic cell operating without a PV/T system, and an additional increase is expected, if the operation was modified to use a nanofluid recirculating pump.
ds temperatures and the system electrical power.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Indoor experiments were conducted to test PV/T systems employing nanofluids consisting of different types of nanoparticles and water as a base fluid. Thermophysical properties such as viscosity, density, thermal conductivity, and fluid stability were studied. A MINI-EEST indoor solar simulator unit was modified and used as a PV/T system cooled by nanofluids.
The results showed that thermal conductivity increased as nanoparticles were added to water. The improvement in thermal conductivity was 1.96, 3.42, and 4.8% for Al2O3, CuO, and SiC nanofluids with 4% volume fractions, respectively. SiC nanofluid showed a higher stability compared to the rest of the nanofluids studied. The lower the volume fraction, the greater the stability of the fluid is. The temperatures of the nanofluids were lower than that of water due to better heat transfer abilities. This property resulted in the system showing an increase in generated power. From the three nanomaterials tested, SiC shows higher stability and thermal conductivity, and was shown to improve the performance of the PV/T system more than the other two nanofluids.

sections.text: The authors would like to thank Solar Energy Research Institute, UKM-Malaysia and Energy and Renewable Energies Technology Research Center, University of Technology-Iraq staff for their support. Also, thanks to Makmal Morfologi CRIM from National University of Malaysia for their support as well.

referenceMentions.context: Moreover, adding nanomaterial to conventional heat transfer fluids improves their thermal properties [1].
The use of nanofluids in solar heat exchangers has attracted considerable attention by researchers recently due to the significant improvement in heat transfer compared to conventional fluids [2].
Maxwell [3] first noted that the addition of solid particles to conventional heat transfer fluids enhances their thermal conductivity.
[4] indicated that a combination of micrometre size solid particles and conventional heat transfer fluids could enhance thermal conductivity.
In a later study, Choi [5] managed to prepare liquids containing nanometre-sized materials.

Viscosity and its changes reflect the resistance of inertia when fluid flows into the system, so adequate information on nanofluid viscosity is necessary to design the proper pumping capacity for convection and heat transfer coefficient of any system [51].

The viscosity resulting from adding nanoparticles to a fluid depends on many factors such as the liquid base, shape and size of the nanoparticles, surface tension and chemistry of particles, temperature, method of dispersion of nanoparticles in suspension, and the resulting nanofluid pH [52,53].

metadata.abstractText: The reduction in efficiency of photovoltaic (PV) units due to increases in cell temperature occurs when a small part of the absorbed solar radiation is converted into electricity and the remaining part is lost as heat. Recently, the addition of a range of nanomaterials with high thermal conductivity to the cooling fluid in PV/T systems has been the subject of much research. In this study, three nanomaterials were added to water as a base fluid with several volume fractions to determine the best concentration and nanoparticle for this application. The PV/T system was setup in an indoor laboratory. Knowing which material has a better effect on the PV unit in particular, and the PV/T unit in general, is important for deciding which nanomaterial is more suitable for the system. The results reveal that nanofluid gives higher thermal conductivity with very little increase in the fluid density and viscosity compared with the base fluid. The studied volume fractions were 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 4% and the selected nanoparticles were Al2O3, CuO, and SiC. It was found that silicon carbide nanoparticles have the best stability and the highest thermal conductivity compared to the other two nano-substances. Copper oxide nanofluid has higher thermal conductivity than aluminium oxide but lower stability, although it was found here that this material reliably stable compared to in other studies. The nanofluid reduced the indoor PV/T system temperature and enhanced its generated power. 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
